soc.message

Class SOCDevCardAction

  • java.lang.Object
    • soc.message.SOCMessage
      • soc.message.SOCMessageForGame
        • soc.message.SOCDevCardAction
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable

    public class SOCDevCardAction
extends SOCMessageForGame
    This message from the server means that a player is drawing or playing a development card; server's response to SOCBuyDevCardRequest or SOCPlayDevCardRequest. See those card types for message sequence details: Sometimes sent to a specific player, sometimes to all other members or to entire game.

    If a robot asks to play a dev card that they can't right now, the server replies to that bot with DevCardAction(-1, CANNOT_PLAY, cardtype).

    Not sent from client, which sends SOCBuyDevCardRequest or SOCPlayDevCardRequest instead. See those message types' javadocs for server's complete response sequences.

    Also sent to client when they sit down to play, to give the private details of their dev card inventory. See VERSION_FOR_SITDOWN_CLEARS_INVENTORY for related details.

    At end of game (state GameState.GAME_OVER), server v2.0.00 and higher reveals players' hidden Victory Point cards by announcing a DevCardAction(pn, ADD_OLD, cardtype [, cardtype, ...]) for each player that has them. (Older server versions used SOCGameTextMsg instead.) Is sent to all game members; a client player should ignore messages about their own cards in state GAME_OVER by checking getPlayerNumber(). That multiple-cardtype form (getCardTypes() != null) is currently used only at end of game.

    Before v2.0.00, this message type was DEVCARD (class name SOCDevCard).

    Author:
    Robert S Thomas
    See Also:
    SOCInventoryItemAction, Serialized Form

    • Field Detail

      • VERSION_FOR_MULTIPLE

        public static final int VERSION_FOR_MULTIPLE
        Minimum client version which can send multiple card types in 1 message: v2.0.00. Same version as SOCPlayerElement.VERSION_FOR_CARD_ELEMENTS.
        Since:
        2.0.00
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • VERSION_FOR_SITDOWN_CLEARS_INVENTORY

        public static final int VERSION_FOR_SITDOWN_CLEARS_INVENTORY
        Minimum client version (2.3.00) where client receiving its player's SOCSitDown message should clear player's currently-unknown inventory contents/dev card count; the server is about to privately send it the detailed contents of that inventory.

        Previous versions were privately sent PLAY messages to clear their unknowns one at a time. If the joining client had been observing the game as player's dev cards were bought, that could cause display bugs where the inventory wasn't entirely cleared out at Sit Down time.

        Similarly, when any version of client joins/sits down to take over a frozen connection, this server version and newer omit unneeded messages which ADD and then clear ("PLAY") unknown cards in that player's inventory.

        Since:
        2.3.00
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • MAX_MULTIPLE

        public static final int MAX_MULTIPLE
        Maximum number of cards to send in a reasonable message: 100.
        Since:
        2.0.00
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • DRAW

        public static final int DRAW
        dev card action DRAW (Buy): Add as new to player's hand
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • PLAY

        public static final int PLAY
        dev card action PLAY: remove as old from player's hand. Sent when actually playing a card, also when clearing player's hand/inventory ("play" SOCDevCardConstants.UNKNOWN) when client is sitting down to take over a bot player.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

        public static final int ADD_NEW
        dev card action ADD_NEW: Add as new to player's hand.

        Before v2.0.00 this was ADDNEW.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

        Before v2.0.00 this was ADDOLD.

      • CANNOT_PLAY

        public static final int CANNOT_PLAY
        dev card action CANNOT_PLAY: The bot can't play the requested card at this time. This is sent only to the requesting robot, so playerNumber is always -1 in this message.
        Since:
        1.1.17
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

    • Constructor Detail

      • SOCDevCardAction

        public SOCDevCardAction(java.lang.String gameName,
                        int pn,
                        int ac,
                        int ct)
        Create a DevCardAction message about 1 card.
        Parameters:
        gameName - name of the game
        pn - the player number, or -1 for action type CANNOT_PLAY
        ac - the type of action
        ct - the type of card, like SOCDevCardConstants.ROADS or SOCDevCardConstants.UNKNOWN
        See Also:
        SOCDevCardAction(String, int, int, List)

      • SOCDevCardAction

        public SOCDevCardAction(java.lang.String gameName,
                        int pn,
                        int ac,
                        java.util.List<java.lang.Integer> ct)
                 throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Create a DevCardAction message about multiple cards. All these cards should have the same flag values (SOCDevCard.isVPCard(int) etc) to avoid client confusion.

        This form is currently used only at end of game (state GameState.GAME_OVER) to reveal hidden Victory Point cards. So, bots ignore it.

        Parameters:
        gameName - name of the game
        pn - the player number; cannot be < 0
        ac - the type of action; cannot be PLAY or CANNOT_PLAY
        ct - the types of card, like SOCDevCardConstants.ROADS or SOCDevCardConstants.UNKNOWN; cannot be null or empty, or longer than MAX_MULTIPLE
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if problem with pn, ac, or ct
        Since:
        2.0.00
        See Also:
        SOCDevCardAction(String, int, int, int)

      • getCardType

        public int getCardType()
        Get the card type, if message is about one card. If about multiple cards, getCardTypes() will be non-null and this field is unused.
        Returns:
        the card type, like SOCDevCardConstants.ROADS or SOCDevCardConstants.UNKNOWN, or 0 (unused) if message uses getCardTypes()

      • getCardTypes

        public java.util.List<java.lang.Integer> getCardTypes()
        Get the card types, if message is about multiple cards.
        Returns:
        list of card types, like SOCDevCardConstants.ROADS or SOCDevCardConstants.UNKNOWN, or null if should use getCardType() instead
        Since:
        2.0.00

        public static SOCDevCardAction parseDataStr(java.lang.String s)

      • stripAttribNames

        public static java.lang.String stripAttribNames(java.lang.String messageTypeName,
                                                java.lang.String messageStrParams)
        Strip out the parameter/attribute names from toString()'s format, returning message parameters as a comma-delimited list for SOCMessage.parseMsgStr(String) to pass to parseDataStr(String). Undoes mapping of action constant integers -> strings ("ADD_NEW" etc). In multi-card form, removes array brackets: ,[5, 4] -> ,5,4.
        Parameters:
        messageTypeName - Message type: v1.x "SOCDevCard" or current "SOCDevCardAction". The SOCDevCardConstants.KNIGHT constant has different values in v1.x vs current.
        messageStrParams - Params part of a message string formatted by toString(); not null
        Returns:
        Message parameters without attribute names, or null if params are malformed
        Since:
        2.4.50

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Description copied from class: SOCMessage
        Simple human-readable delimited representation, used for debug purposes: SOCPutPiece:game=test5|playerNumber=3|pieceType=0|coord=40a
        Could also be used by a SOCServer.recordGameEvent(String, SOCMessage) implementation.

        Within this representation, message parameters should be in same order used by SOCMessage.toCmd() and parseDataStr(..). Should be parseable by SOCMessage.parseMsgStr(String) which calls SOCMessage.stripAttribNames(String), which your class can override if needed.

        Overrides:
        toString in class SOCMessageForGame
        Returns:
        a human readable form of the message
        See Also:
        SOCMessage.toCmd()
